text.p: Here are the highlights of stories in Serbian and Montenegrin press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories nor does it vouch for their accuracy.
-- SERBIA --
NASA BORBA
- Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic visited the mainly-Albanian province of Kosovo on Wednesday and said the republic will not yield an inch of Kosovo and Metohija.
- The talks between Yugoslavia and London Club on restructure and reschedule of some $2.4 billion debt probably to resume in July in Belgrade.
- Federal parliament session to discuss on Thursday more than 40 bills and amendmends to the laws seen as a framework for further economic reforms.
- Nine electoral units was a limit of proportional electoral system, the Democratic Party os Serbia said after talks with the government on the bill on local government moving for 29.
- The Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS) might call republic's elections end of September, said vice-president of the Serbian Radical Party Tomislav Nikolic.
- Ethnic Albanian parties in Kosovo boycotted Milosevic's visit.

- Participants of a three-day round table talks between ethnic Albanians and Serbian representatives called for a peaceful solution of Kosovo crisis and more constructive role of the internatinal community.
- Sulejman Ugljanin, president of the Moslem National Council for Sandzak, said the region has had not given up the idea on autonomy.
- The Alliance of Vojvodina Hungarians say they will prevent the passage of a bill on local government.
- Foreign partners are interested in investing in agriculture, said Milomir Obradovic, executive director of Agrabanka.
- NIS Energogas to initiate construction of transBalkan gas pipeline from Russia to Italy via Yugoslav territory.
- Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, says if the party participates in the elections then it will do so independently of its coalition partners.
POLITIKA
- The Serbian government adopts the draft on ownership transformation.
- Yugoslav and Greek prime ministers, Radoje Kontic and Costas Simitis, confirmed in Athens wide cooperation between the two countries.

- Harvest in Yugoslavia's bread-basket of Vojvodina started on Wednesday where some 356,000 hectares was sown with wheat this year, up 30 percent on the area sown in 1996. An average yield of 3.82 tonnes is expected this year which would result in production of 530,000 tonnes of wheat, up 64 percent on 1996 harvest.
- Yugoslav average wage in May increased by 0.1 percent to 734 dinars. Highest wage of 2,051 dinars was in oil and gas production companies and the lowest of 186 dinars was in textile industry.
- Some $80 million to be invested by the year 2000 in reconstruction of Yugoslav copper ore mine in Majdanpek.

- Serbian Prime Minister Mirko Marjanovic said draft on ownership transformation was just, respects autonomy of the enterprises, prevents sale and undervaluation of social and state property, stimulates reforms, prevents concentration of capital, encourages foreign investments, contributes to the solution of the old foreign currency savings, cares of big state-firms which employ large workforce and respects the principle of social justice.
VECERNJE NOVOSTI

- Acting central bank governor Bozidar Gazivoda confiremd money supply M1 increased but was based on cuntry's foreign currency reserves rise which resulted from the partial sale of Telekom Srbija. Solvent enterprises can use unlimited amount of foreign currency, he said.
- Serbian health minsiter Leposava Milicevic announced reforms in the health system without labour cuts.
-- MONTENGRO --
POBJEDA
- Editor in chief of TV Montenegro Vladimir Asanin resigned on Wednesday.
- Montenegro must import 78 million KWh of electricity in July at the value of $2.27 billion. Republic's power company Elektroprivreda Crne Gore does not have that money.
- Montenegro's shipping company Jugooceanija of Kotor will get $4 million loan from London based Anglo-Yugoslav bank to overhaul four vessels. -- Belgrade Newsroom +381 11 222 4254
